prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Organics in Enceladus Plume
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect organic molecules (namely HCN) in the water plume emanating from the south pole of Enceladus.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: The time listed above is a representative time window of when the periapsis of Enceladus's orbit will be visible. Enceladus has an orbital period of 33 hours, so the time of periapsis will coincide with a visible time window (ie Saturn at a reasonable elevation) roughly 5 times within C36-3 and 9 times within C36-3/4. We are not restricted to any specific one of these events, but are flexible to take observations within any of the recurring events (ie in the event of the configuration schedule being shifted). See Technical Justification for more details.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Of the detected organic constituents of the Enceladus plume, only HCN, H2CO, and CH3OH are expected to be readily detectable by ALMA (given current plume models and measured abundances). Based on the measured abundances and intrinsic line strengths, HCN will be the most detectable species, and so we target it for this proposal.
Our choice of the J=3-2 transition of HCN is driven by our temperature assumptions (see Scientific Justification), and the balance between higher line strengths at high J but higher populations at low J due to the fairly cold temperature. Figure 2 only displays simulations for the 3-2 transition, but we simulated all transitions up to J_upper=5, determining that the J=3-2 transition should be the brightest and most robust to deviations in temperature from our model assumptions.
Our spectral resolution on the HCN line is driven by our assumed linewidth of 1 km/s. The linewidth of a jet like the Enceladus plume will be dominated by the spread of gas velocity, and we derive a linewidth of approximately 1 km/s using a gas velocity of 1000m/s (Dong et al 2011), and a south pole inclination of 27 degrees away from the observer for Enceladus. Values suggested for the gas velocity range from 400 m/s to 2600m/s, so our requested resolution of ~0.08km/s gives us the flexibility to resolve a wide variety of linewidths and gas velocities. This is necessary for our science goal of determining the plume dynamics through measurement of the gas velocity.
Given our choice of the HCN 3-2 line, our possible selections of other relevant lines are sparse. We place another window on the HCO+ 3-2 line in hopes of tracing the ionization in the upper layers of Enceladus' atmosphere.
Finally, we have two continuum windows, yielding a high continuum sensitivity for self-calibration, necessary for achieving our desired rms goals. These measurements will also yield a brightness temperature for Enceladus.
An additional consideration is that Enceladus has a relatively high spread of radial velocities, given its fast orbit of Saturn. The OT does not seem to update the source velocity from the Ephemeris, but it is roughly -10 km/s. Within the span of our observations, the velocity should only change by roughly 7km/s, so any line emission will still be within our spectral window. We will be able to correct for this velocity shift as a function of time when reducing the data.

The size of the plume is not well constrained, but we estimate that given a Mach ~2 supersonic jet, it will not extend over 2 arcseconds, meaning that the ACA will not be necessary.
Based on our model (Figure 2), a beam of 0.4" should be able to marginally resolve the plume, although this depends heavily on the temperature distribution within the plume (see Scientific Justification for rationale of our temperature choice). Constraining the shape of the plume is not one of our main goals, but if possible will aid in our goal of better understanding the plume dynamics.
Due to the time constraints surrounding observations of an orbiting object such as Enceladus, we note that we are flexible between configurations C36-3 and C36-4. Figure 2 simulations were obtained using C36-3, but C36-4 simulations yielded similar recovery of our model flux, and comparable SNRs. 0.4" is the maximum resolution that will still allow us to resolve the plume and accomplish our science goals, but resolutions down to 0.2" will not significantly adversly affect our sensitivity.

As seen in the Science Justification figure 3, we expect a line intensity on the order of 60 mJy/bm for our model based on Dong et al (2011). However in order to make a definitive statement about the abundance of HCN in the event of a non-detection, we need to rather consider the most pessimistic model that is reasonable. Figure 3 shows that the expected HCN flux of this model is roughly 15 mJy/bm, so we request a sensitivity of 3 mJy/bm in order to have a 5 sigma detection in this pessimistic case (or a 5 sigma exclusion of Cassini level HCN abundances in the case of a non-detection).
For these calculations, we assume a bandwidth of 0.13 km/s, ie spectral averaging our requested bandwidth resolution by a factor of two. This bandwidth is still enough to resolve the line while providing better sensitivity, and is the width used in Figure 3.

As noted previously, the time window and ephemeris give above are representative of a generic window when the periapsis of Enceladus's orbit will be visible. Below are a number of technical restrictions that will be important to consider for this project. These constraints make the project more difficult to observe, but we believe it to still be technically feasible.
- C36-3 is listed as being between Apr 19 - May 10th in 2016, with a midnight LST ranging from 15-16 hrs - Enceladus orbits around Saturn with a period of 33 hour, or 1 day and 9 hrs - Saturn stays relatively fixed in the sky over C36-3 time, at an RA of ~17 hrs (see ephemeris)
- Enceladus ranges from 35 to 15 arcseconds separation from Saturn over the course of its orbit, this is 3.5-1.5 Saturn radii (and roughly 1.5-0.8 primary beams at band 6) Our observations must occur while at least 1 primary beam away from Saturn, given its extreme radio strength - The plume is strongest at periapsis (Hedman et al. 2011) - this happens to be at roughly 30 arcseconds separation, and should remain roughly constant, because the Saturn system is not rotating quickly with respect to us - Thus the time we want to observe for radio contamination concerns is also the time we want to observe because of plume strength
- We can assume Saturn is visible with a good elevation for roughly 9 hours each day, with most of that time being at night. - The time that a periapsis observation of Enceladus is available will rotate by 9 hours, given the orbital period - Given these parameters, a periapsis observation of Enceladus will be possible roughly 5 times within C36-3, and 9 times within C36-3/4
Thus we wish to stress that although the observations are time constrained, there will be multiple opportunities to make the observations, and we are flexible to at least two antenna configurations. Additionally, the observations may be split over two Scheduling Blocks without signficantly affecting our science goals.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Enceladus, one of Saturn's major moons, is the source of a spectacular water plume. This plume provides a unique possibility to trace the composition of an underground water reservoir in the outer Solar System remotely. Excitingly, Cassini has measured high abundances of small organic molecules such as HCN and H$_2$CO in the plume, suggestive of a rich underwater organic chemistry. More detailed and confident characterization of the plume by Cassini will be difficult, however, due to a lack of planned flybys after September 2015, insufficient instrumentation to quantify the organic composition, and a persistent worry that some of the organics Cassini is `measuring' may be residual from Titan flybys. We propose to use ALMA to obtain an independent data set securing the existence of the most detectable plume organic, HCN, allowing us to quantify its abundance relative to water and from there assess whether the HCN/H$_2$O abundance seems cometary or the result of an evolving, planetary chemistry.
